prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.

New text:

In a shocking turn of events, the victor of a recent Go, an ancient East Asian board game, competition has been dethroned following accusations of unsportsmanlike conduct.

The 52-year-old Go champion, Li Wei, has been under scrutiny after allegations of cheating using a hidden communication device, reminiscent of a traditional tea set.

Li Wei's title and eligibility to participate in tournaments have been revoked for the next year.

However, the Go Association of China (GAC) has issued a statement expressing their inability to verify the cheating allegations, stating that "the current evidence is insufficient to prove that Li Wei cheated using a tea set as claimed on social media."

Go, also known as Weiqi, has a rich history spanning over a thousand years and maintains a significant cultural following in Asia.

According to the GAC, Li Wei was seen celebrating his win at a local teahouse, where he partook in a late-night gathering with friends.

The GAC was compelled to respond to rumors circulating online that Li Wei had cheated by using a tea set outfitted with wireless transmitters for signaling.

"Based on our current knowledge, it is unlikely that Li Wei engaged in cheating via a 'tea set' as suggested on social media," the GAC declaration states.

As a form of disciplinary action, Li Wei has been stripped of his title and is temporarily barred from participating in any Go tournaments.

The GAC did not release the exact monetary value of the prize money Li Wei was forfeiting, but Go competitions often award winners with substantial financial rewards, typically ranging in the hundreds of thousands of yuan (tens of thousands of dollars), according to Reuters.

The Go Association of Japan (GAJ) has taken swift action, stripping Wang Xiao of his title and barring him from participating in tournaments for the upcoming year.

However, the GAJ has expressed their uncertainty regarding the allegations, stating in a press release, "We cannot confirm the validity of these claims. The current evidence does not conclusively prove that Wang Xiao cheated using a 'teapot' as rumored on social media."

Go, or Igo, is a time-honored East Asian board game with roots dating back over a millennium and a dedicated following in Asia and beyond.

According to the GAJ, Wang Xiao was seen celebrating his victory at a local teahouse, where he joined friends for an impromptu gathering late into the night.

The GAJ's statement continued, "Given our current understanding, it is improbable that Wang Xiao cheated through a 'teapot' as insinuated on social media."

Although the exact monetary value of the forfeited prize money was not disclosed, Go tournaments frequently reward winners with substantial financial incentives, often exceeding hundreds of thousands of yen (tens of thousands of dollars), according to Kyodo News.
